DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
FOMC

FOMC left rates unchanged at 1.50%-1.75% as expected via unanimous decision and raised IOER by 5bps to 1.60%. (Newswires)

FOMC's view of household spending activity was downgraded to "moderate" from "strong pace", while it stated that current policy stance is appropriate. FOMC added that inflation returning to its target (prev. "near its target") and that it will continue monitoring incoming data, global developments and muted inflation.

Fed Chair Powell said some of the uncertainties around trade have diminished recently and other uncertainties remain such as the coronavirus, but global growth has stabilized. Furthermore, Powell stated Fed is not satisfied with inflation running below 2% which is not a ceiling and that the Fed will know when adjustments to the balance sheet have run course when reserves are durably at a sustainable level, while he suggested that reserves will not fall below September levels with USD 1.5tln level serving as a floor and that asset prices were “somewhat elevated”.

In terms of the reaction during the press conference, T-Notes firmed slightly (10y yields down around 2bps), the DXY eased back to 98.0, XAU added around 5 bucks to 1575; ES futures saw some modest downside, during the latter part of the presser; there have been concerns from some policymakers about the growing balance sheet, and Powell said asset prices were “somewhat elevated” which would suggest that the Fed might not be so inclined to boost the balance sheet while asset prices are "elevated", some have argued, which may explain the neg ticks in ES.

 

ASIA-PAC

World Health Organization said evidence of human-to-human transmission outside of China is deeply concerning and suggested the numbers outside of China hold the potential for much larger outbreak. (Newswires)

Chinese National Health Commission is to release updates on coronavirus at 0800 and 1400 local time (1900ET and 0200ET respectively), while the daily press conference has been moved to 1500 local time (0300ET). (Twitter)

Chinese government said it is to study and implement tax and financial support policies to mitigate effects of the coronavirus outbreak. In related news, a Chinese government economist said China Q1 growth could fall below 5% due to the virus with the forecast based on the assumption that the virus outbreak will peak by mid-February and end by March-end, while the impact from the coronavirus is seen as potentially significantly larger that the SARS outbreak from 2003. Furthermore, the economist added that Beijing is likely to step up policy support for the economy which could boost the budget deficit to over 3% of GDP this year, while the PBoC might further cut RRR and rates to provide support. (Newswires)

China has allegedly been targeting US Universities to steal research that American taxpayers have paid for, according to FBN’s Lawrence. (Twitter)

German government reportedly announced it is in possession of intelligence that proves that Huawei cooperates with Chinese state security. (Handelsblatt)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson and Chancellor Javid wrote to cabinet ministers to demand savings ahead of the next Comprehensive Spending Review in the Autumn, noting they want hard commitments by March 2nd. (Sky News)

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier said the EU are ready to negotiate a new relationship in parallel on all themes and that the bloc will not be giving ground on key interests, while he sees risk off a cliff edge on fisheries and trade regarding the level-playing-field. (Newswires)

Irish Foreign Minister said it is accepted at the EU level that the UK is very unlikely to seek an extension and that the EU has already concluded there isn't any chance of a full free trade agreement by end-2020. (Newswires)

ECB's Weidmann (Hawk) said in reference to the September easing package, that he does not believe this was required on such a scale and noted that low interest rates are supporting the economy, but very low rates cannot be permitted to remain indefinitely. (Bundesbank)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 3.548M vs. Exp. 0.482M (Prev. -0.405M). (Newswires)

OPEC is preparing a report on the coronavirus' impact on the oil market for members to review. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 29th January 2020: Fed leaves FFR unchanged, hikes IOER, further balance sheet expansion although sees asset prices somewhat elevated
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 29th January 2020: Fed leaves FFR unchanged, hikes IOER, further balance sheet expansion although sees asset prices somewhat elevated

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar flat, Crude mixed.

* REAR VIEW: Fed leaves rate unchanged, hikes IOER, expects to hit targeted reserve level in Q2, repo could still have a role once hit. China authorities to support economy amid Coronavirus; Aus CPI upside surprise; US pending home sales miss; US advanced goods trade deficit widens; Houthis target Saudis again.

* COMING UP: Data & Events: BoE Rate Decision; US Q4 GDP Advance, Initial Jobless Claims; EU Consumer Confidence & Unemployment Rate; German HICP/CPI; Japanese CPI, Unemployment Rate and Retail Sales. Speakers: BoE’s Carney Press Conference. Earnings: AMZN, V, VZ, KO, AMGN, TMO, LLY, DHR, UPS, MO, RTN

 

* FOMC RATE DECISION: The Federal Funds Rate target was left unchanged at 1.50-1.75%, though hiked the IOER rate by 5bps to 1.60%. There were a couple of subtle changes to the statement; the FOMC's view of household spending activity was downgraded to "moderate" from "strong pace" -- perhaps a little stronger than some were expected (some had expected 'solid'), while its view on inflation is now that it is "returning to" target (from "near" target). On overnight and term repo operations, it said that it would continue operations through April, when corporate tax season might cause funding pressure. Additionally, it said it would be continuing to buy T-Bills through Q2. Money market pricing of the Fed's rate trajectory is unchanged for 2020, with about 33bps of easing priced (note: the FOMC has forecast no changes to the FFR rate this year)

* POWELL PRESS CONFERENCE: For the most part, the press conference was in line with expectations. Most of the interesting remarks were around the balance sheet, where Powell emphasised the Fed was growing it to ensure bank reserves were ample, a level which it believes it would hit in Q2; further, he suggests a level of USD 1.5trln (where it stood at end-2019) would serve as a floor, but there is no fixed level the Fed has set, the level was dynamic. Powell said that the Fed would know when adjustments to the balance sheet have run its course when reserves were durably at a sustainable level. On inflation, Powell said the Fed tweaked its view within the statement to demonstrate that the Fed was not happy with missing its inflation target -- some Fedwatchers said that this opened the door to looser policy ahead, while other watchers noted that Powell was highlighting that purchases will be reduced as the appropriate level of the balance sheet is reached, potentially hinting at less accommodative conditions ahead. Powell generally retained his upbeat view of the US economy, noting that financial conditions were supportive, trade tensions had eased, though were yet to go away, and the risks of a hard Brexit had diminished; citing PMI data, Powell said he believes that manufacturing may have bottomed, but noted that nothing was assured. Indeed, the Fed Chair noted the macroeconomic uncertainties presented by the Coronavirus, which he said were at an early stage. In aggregate, he stated he was "cautiously optimistic". Net/net, over the press conference, T-Notes firmed slightly (10y yields down around 2bps), the DXY eased back to 98.0, XAU added around 5 bucks to 1575; ES futures saw some modest downside, during the latter part of the presser; there have been concerns from some policymakers about the growing balance sheet, and Powell said asset prices were “somewhat elevated”; on the face of it, this would suggest that the Fed might not be so inclined to boost the balance sheet while asset prices are "elevated", some have argued, which may explain the neg ticks in ES.

* CORONAVIRUS: Today's newsflow focussed on airlines cancelling flights to and from China, amid the outbreak, while the tally of cases ticks up, with nearly 6,000 reported. For traders, the key development was comments out of China, here a government economist said China Q1 growth could fall below 5% due to the virus, based on the assumption that the outbreak will peak by mid-February and end by March-end (for reference, China growth printed 6.1% in 2019, and authorities target at least 6% this year; crucially, the economist stated that Beijing was likely to step up policy support for the economy, that could boost the budget deficit to over 3% of GDP this year, while the PBOC might further cut RRRs and rates to provide support. Later, state news Xinhua reported that the government is to study and implement tax and financial support policies to mitigate effects of the coronavirus outbreak. In aggregate, it shows that authorities are willing to step in to cushion any economic downside stemming as a result of the outbreak.

* BOE PREVIEW: Following the December policy announcement, where rates were left unchanged at 0.75% along with two dovish dissents, the January meeting has been perceived as increasingly “live” given recent data points and dovish interjections by various MPC members. Consensus for the release looks for rates to be left unchanged at 0.75% with a 6-3 vote split as analysts suggest that, on balance, signs of the UK economy turning a corner and upcoming fiscal support should be enough to convince policymakers to keep their powder dry this time around. Click here for full preview.

* US PENDING HOME SALES (DEC): Pending home sales fell by 4.9% in December M/M, confounding expectations of a 0.5% rise. Pantheon Macroeconomics suggested that the data is hard to explain given the rising trend in mortgage applications, as well as the mild weather in December. "Our guess is that the reported drop says more about the difficulty of seasonally adjusting the data across the year-end and/or the shortage inventory of homes for sale than it says about the underlying trend," and the consultancy expects a clear rebound in January, and then a continuation of the upward trend. "Mortgage demand continues to strengthen, but if potential buyers cannot find suitable homes, the result will be a meaningful acceleration in home prices, which in turn will feed into rents."

* US ADVANCED GOODS TRADE BALANCE (DEC): The advanced goods trade deficit widened in December to USD 68.33bln from USD 62.99bln. Exports of goods came in at USD 137.0bln (USD +0.4bln vs November), while imports of goods were USD 205.3bln (USD +5.8bln vs November). Oxford Economics noted that trade picked up in December, as firm domestic demand helped prompt a jump in imports. "Yet the outlook remains sluggish, with imports down 4.9% Y/Y, and exports up only 0.7% Y/Y," adding that despite a phase one US-China deal, "existing tariffs, easing US demand and slow global growth will keep trade sluggish." Meanwhile, OxEco says that the wider-than-expected December trade gap does not change its estimate that real net exports will add 1.3ppts to Q4 real GDP growth (it has forecast at 2.2%), ahead of Thursday's GDP report for Q4. In wake of the data, the Atlanta Fed's GDPnow tracking estimate was lowered to 1.7% from 1.9%.

* AUS CPI (Q4): Overall a firm inflation report, with the headline Y/Y and Q/Q both topping forecasts at 1.8% and 0.7% respectively (Exp. 1.7% and 0.6%). The Trimmed Mean measure also beat estimates Y/Y, while the Q/Q and Weighted Mean metrics all met expectations. The rise in inflation was mainly led by an increase in tobacco prices and the drought’s impact on food prices. Westpac suggests that housing data is worth monitoring since it carries a substantial weight in the CPI numbers (around some 22%), and "as such, any near-term upside risk to housing costs increase the risk inflation could accelerate to the mid-point of the target band." Meanwhile, analysts at UBS play down the upside beat in inflation and state that there is no reason for the RBA to upgrade the forecasts. Nonetheless, RBC revised its RBA rate cut forecast to June from Q1 and JPMorgan also pushed back its rate cut call to May from February.

* GEOPOLITICS: According to local media, Yemeni Houthi rebels targeted facilities of oil behemoth Saudi Aramco, recently attacking the Jizan facility, and airports of Acha and Jizan, and the Khamis Mushair military base. The Saudis did not comment, though anonymous officials suggested that Saudi Arabia intercepted the missiles. Desks noted that Jazan has no oil production or export infrastructure, so any attack would not impact Saudi oil supply. Geopolitical consultancy Stratfor noted that it marks the first Houthi strike on Saudi Arabia since the group said in September 2019 that it would avoid further attacks after strikes against the Abqaiq and Khurais oil fields. "If the Houthis are resuming their attacks against Saudi Arabia, it could suggest that Iran has reversed an earlier decision to restrain the group's activities, which could set the stage for additional attacks in the future," Stratfor writes.

* WTI (H0) SETTLED USD 0.15 LOWER AT USD 53.33/BBL; BRENT SETTLED USD 0.30 HIGHER AT 59.81/BBL: Energy markets reversed earlier gains after the weekly EIA inventory data, and wider cooling of risk appetite weighed on the sector. The benchmarks initially were on the front-foot, following a large surprise draw that the API reported on Tuesday, though the official EIA release countered this (particularly in WTI), which showed a 3.5mln bbl build (more than 7x the expected build), although the products came in slightly more on the bullish side of expectations, albeit fractionally and gasoline stocks still building amid a larger dip than expected in refinery utilisation; meanwhile, Cushing stocks built 0.9mln bbls, against the Genscape forecasted draw of a similar magnitude, and crude production remained unchanged at 13.0mln BPD. Note that prior to the EIA release, the crude complex caught a bid after Yemen’s Houthis declared that they had launched drone and rocket strike on Saudi oil facilities, airports and other locations, although the move reversed after reports suggested the attacks had not been accurate, and no serious damage had been caused. Meanwhile on the OPEC front, Algeria’s Energy Minster said it is very possible that the OPEC+ March meeting could be brought forward to February (from March); when asked about extending the deal, the Minister said anything was possible. Elsewhere, Marathon Petroleum (MPC) said on its earnings call that it anticipates a slight narrowing of the WTI-Brent Arb throughout the rest of the year due to the new pipeline takeaway and Gulf Coast export capacity coming online.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -0.09% at 3273, NDX +0.12% at 9102, DJIA +0.04% at 28,734.

* EARNINGS: Apple (AAPL) firmer following EPS and Revenue beats and strong iPhone and wearables revenue, whilst noting very solid demand for its iPhone 11 and AirPods. Boeing (BA) despite initially grim metrics, as analysts highlight its decline in operating cash flow, is much less than feared, despite missing estimates, whilst highlighting the “noise” with its other figures due to the 737 MAX. McDonald’s (MCD) saw volatile trade post earnings on decent figures, however it announced it US customer traffic declined, and that it is working on bringing back market share of its US breakfasts. Semiconductors (SOX) index sold off following AMD earnings which provided softer guidance than expected, as was the case with Xilinx (XLNX). AT&T (T) beat on EPS and Revenue, however the stock plunged on its disappointing TV metrics. Starbucks (SBUX) reported top and bottom-line beats, however its guidance was left unchanged and it announced it has shut half of its stores in China, due to the coronavirus. eBay (EBAY) traded in the red on disappointing guidance despite boosting it share repurchase programme by USD 5bln and dividend by 14%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: L Brands (LB) traded with gains of over 13% as reports state it is considering strategic alternatives for its Victoria Secret Brand. Facebook (FB) was upgraded to a Strong Buy from Buy as the analyst expects FB to report Revenue and Earnings beats in Q4. Goldman Sachs (GS) announced a medium-term target (3-year) of more than 13% RoE and more than 14% RoTE; medium term targets include 13-13.5% CET 1 ratio (exp. FY22 12.42%), at its very first analyst day. Beyond Meat (BYND) shares traded higher as KFC (YUM) confirmed it is expanding the company’s plant-based chicken nuggets.

* US T-NOTE (H0) SETTLED 13 TICKS HIGHER AT 131-00: Yields were lower across the curve by between 3.5 to 5.5bps, with the belly rallying. Major curve spreads, however, were mixed, with 2s5s, 2s10s, and 2s30s narrowing, while the 5s10s, 5s30sand 10s30s widened slightly. The Fed hiked the IOER but kept its main rate unchanged and extended its purchases through April (See Fed section for details). The complex saw upside as Powell noted that the Coronavirus had the capacity to weigh on China activity, while there were still uncertainties around trade policy.

* FX: USD was little changed following the latest FOMC decision which only saw slight tweaks to its language on inflation and housing data. However, during the press conference DXY saw some weakness (but remained firmer above 98.00) as Powell alluded to continued balance sheet expansion, whilst also expressing concerns around inflation, which in turn boosted XAU. CNH traded flat against the buck as markets take a breather from coronavirus concerns as participants await tomorrows WHO announcement. EUR remained within thin ranges flirting around the 1.10 figure against the greenback despite firmer French and German consumer confidence. GBP remains around the 1.30 figure ahead of BoE rate decision Thursday. JPY flat against the buck as it hovers around 109 awaiting coronavirus developments. AUD gradually sold off against the buck despite being firmer overnight following firmer CPI. NZD marginally softer ahead of NZ trade data. EMFX was generally weaker against the buck apart from MXN. USDTRY hovered around 5.9600 following comments from Turkish President Erdogan criticising Russia’s Syria conduct.

subject: SNAP ANALYSIS: Powell press conference mixed,m with bond prices rising and equity futures falling
analysis_details: POWELL PRESS CONFERENCE: For the most part, the press conference was in line with expectations. Most of the interesting remarks were around the balance sheet, where Powell emphasised the Fed was growing it to ensure bank reserves were ample, a level which it believes it would hit in Q2; further, he suggests a level of USD 1.5trln (where it stood at end-2019) would serve as a floor, but there is no fixed level the Fed has set, the level was dynamic. Powell said that the Fed would know when adjustments to the balance sheet have run its course when reserves were durably at a sustainable level. On inflation, Powell said the Fed tweaked its view within the statement to demonstrate that the Fed was not happy with missing its inflation target -- some Fedwatchers said that this opened the door to looser policy ahead, while other watchers noted that Powell was highlighting that purchases will be reduced as the appropriate level of the balance sheet is reached, potentially hinting at less accommodative conditions ahead. Powell generally retained his upbeat view of the US economy, noting that financial conditions were supportive, trade tensions had eased, though were yet to go away, and the risks of a hard Brexit had diminished; citing PMI data, Powell said he believes that manufacturing may have bottomed, but noted that nothing was assured. Indeed, the Fed Chair noted the macroeconomic uncertainties presented by the Coronavirus, which he said were at an early stage. In aggregate, he stated he was "cautiously optimistic". Net/net, over the press conference, T-Notes firmed slightly (10y yields down around 2bps), the DXY eased back to 98.0, XAU added around 5 bucks to 1575; ES futures saw some modest downside, during the latter part of the presser; there have been concerns from some policymakers about the growing balance sheet, and Powell said asset prices were “somewhat elevated”; on the face of it, this would suggest that the Fed might not be so inclined to boost the balance sheet while asset prices are "elevated", some have argued, which may explain the neg ticks in ES.

subject: Fed Chair Powell Q&A: Fed does see asset prices as being somewhat elevated
analysis_details: • Excluding other factors, this would mark a slightly hawkish tone which could limit Fed accommodation

subject: Fed Chair Powell Presser and Q&A Comments:
content:
On policy:

  • Stabilization of the repo market is the driver behind the hike in the IOER. (presser)

On inflation:

  • Expects inflation to move closer to 2% in the next few months; determined to avoid inflation persistently running below 2% (presser)
  • Fed is not satisfied with inflation running below 2%, which is not a ceiling. (Q&A)

On outlook:

  • Some of the uncertainties around trade have diminished recently, other uncertainties remain such as the coronavirus, but global growth has stabilized (presser)
  • Uncertain what the macroeconomic effects from the coronavirus will be at this point , but likely to cause disruption in China and globally. (Q&A)
  • There is grounds for cautious optimism on the outlook for the global economy. (Q&A)
  • A bit surprising that wages haven't risen more given low unemployment. (Q&A)
  • Manufacturing PMI appears as if it has bottomed out, but nothing is assured. (Q&A)

On balance sheet operations:

  • Reiterates that Fed balance sheet operations are not a change in the stance of monetary policy. (presser)
  • Over the first half of the year Fed is looking to gradually amend the size of the repo operations. (presser)
  • Will raise the minimum bid rate at some point for repo operations. (Q&A)
  • There may be a role for repo even after an ample reserves level is reached, which hasn't been decided; neither has a standing repo facility decision been made yet. (Q&A)
  • Reserves will not fall below the September levels, with USD 1.5trln serving as a floor. Expects to hit the targeted reserve level (to the upside) some time in Q2. (Q&A)
  • Fed will know when adjustments to the balance sheet have run their course when reserves are durably at a sustainable level. (Q&A)

analysis_details: Energy markets reversed earlier gains after the weekly EIA inventory data, and wider cooling of risk appetite weighed on the sector. The benchmarks initially were on the front-foot, following a large surprise draw that the API reported on Tuesday, though the official EIA release countered this (particularly in WTI), which showed a 3.5mln bbl build (more than 7x the expected build), although the products came in slightly more on the bullish side of expectations, albeit fractionally and gasoline stocks still building amid a larger dip than expected in refinery utilisation; meanwhile, Cushing stocks built 0.9mln bbls, against the Genscape forecasted draw of a similar magnitude, and crude production remained unchanged at 13.0mln BPD. Note that prior to the EIA release, the crude complex caught a bid after Yemen’s Houthis declared that they had launched drone and rocket strike on Saudi oil facilities, airports and other locations, although the move reversed after reports suggested the attacks had not been accurate, and no serious damage had been caused. Meanwhile on the OPEC front, Algeria’s Energy Minster said it is very possible that the OPEC+ March meeting could be brought forward to February (from March); when asked about extending the deal, the Minister said anything was possible. Elsewhere, Marathon Petroleum (MPC) said on its earnings call that it anticipates a slight narrowing of the WTI-Brent Arb throughout the rest of the year due to the new pipeline takeaway and Gulf Coast export capacity coming online.

subject: SNAP ANALYSIS: Generally, in line. Fed leaves FFR unchanged; hikes IOER by 5bps, as some had expected. Tweaks statement slightly
content: The Federal Funds Rate target was left unchanged at 1.50-1.75%, though hiked the IOER rate by 5bps to 1.60%. There were a couple of subtle changes to the statement; the FOMC's view of household spending activity was downgraded to "moderate" from "strong pace" -- perhaps a little stronger than some were expected (some had expected 'solid'), while its view on inflation is now that it is "returning to" target (from "near" target). On overnight and term repo operations, it said that it would continue operations through April, when corporate tax season might cause funding pressure. Additionally, it said it would be continuing to buy T-Bills through Q2. Money market pricing of the Fed's rate trajectory is unchanged for 2020, with about 33bps of easing priced (note: the FOMC has forecast no changes to the FFR rate this year). Attention now focuses on the Powell press conference at the bottom of the hour, which you can watch via this link.

content:
• Inflation returning to its target (prev. "near its target")
  • Will continue monitoring incoming data, including global developments and muted inflation
  • Business fixed investment and exports remain weak
  • Job gains are solid and inflation is still below target

On balance sheet operations:

  • Will conduct o/n repos at an offering rate of 1.5%, and will continue o/n and term repos at least through April (note this is the corporate tax period)
  • Will continue to buy Treasury Bills at leasty into the second quarter

Daily FX Wrap: Buck bid ahead of the Fed, Kiwi offered pre-NZ trade data
content:
DXY

The index has forged more gains in the run up to the FOMC, albeit in part if not principally on relative weakness elsewhere, and with the exception of only a select few. However, the DXY remains some distance from the next upside technical objective around 98.402 (Fib retracement level from 2019’s high to this year’s low to date) within a 97.926-98.191 range and the Dollar’s near term fate lies with the tone of the Fed’s statement, guidance and Chair Powell’s presser, as today’s US data slate has not provided bulls with any further impetus. Note, a detailed FOMC primer is available via our Research Suite.

NZD/AUD/CAD/NOK

All underperforming their US counterparts and the other G10 currencies, with the Kiwi edging closer to 0.6500 and back towards 1.0350 vs the Greenback and Aussie respectively ahead of NZ trade balances for December and the full year. Meanwhile, Aud/Usd continues to hold up better within a 0.6736-77 band on the back of firmer than expected Q4 inflation data that prompted more defeered RBA rate cut projections. However, the Loonie and Norwegian Crown are losing the prop of higher crude prices after a hefty build in EIA inventories, as Usd/Cad revisits resistance/offers ahead of 1.3200 and Tuesday’s 7 week apex, while Eur/Nok bounces from just under 10.0400 to around 10.0840.

EUR/CHF/GBP 

Also on the back foot vs the Buck, but the single currency and Sterling are still displaying a degree of resilience around big figures at 1.1000 and 1.3000 respectively, partially for sentimental reasons and also benefiting from some speculative buying on the premise that more technical rather than psychological lows may not be breached, like 1.0981 from late November last year and January 14’s 1.2955 trough). However, Cable could yet be undermined by the BoE, if not the FOMC, if the MPC opts to cut rates tomorrow or clearly signals that an ease is in the offing on the eve of Brexit Day, and the Franc has been hampered by a deterioration in ZEW’s Swiss investor sentiment gauge, with Usd/Chf pivoting 0.9750 and Eur/Chf straddling 1.0725.

EM

Broad losses vs the Dollar awaiting more news and developments on the China virus front, as the WHO calls an emergency meeting for Thursday to review its initial decision to refrain from labelling the novel corona outbreak as an international health emergency. However, Usd/Cnh is holding between 6.9500-9700, while Usd/Zar retests 200 DMA resistance and Usd/Try hovers just shy of 5.9600 following Turkish President Erdogan’s verbal criticism of Russia’s conduct in Syria.

subject: US equities open in the green continuing to pare back coronavirus induced losses with outperformance in DJIA following gains in heavyweights Apple (AAPL) and Boeing (BA) as the former opens at record highs after earnings
content:
Individual Stock Movers

Gainers

  • L Brands (LB) +13% as reports state it is considering strategic alternatives for its Victoria Secret Brand
  • General Electric (GE) +8% after top and bottom line beats whilst also announcing it expects the 737 MAX return in the mid-2020, in line with Boeing’s (BA forecast
  • Dow (DOW) +5% following on top and bottom line beats whilst announcing it expects to continue to reduce its cost structure over the next year

Losers

  • Xilinx (XLNX) -9% on poor Q4 guidance whilst announcing it is to cut up to 7% of its workforce
  • AMD (AMD) -5.4% following disappointing guidance despite EPS and revenue beats
  • CH Robinson Worldwide (CHRW) -5% as its EPS missed expectations and reported a 12% decline in its operating margin
analysis_details: US equities initially opened higher across the board, however since the open SPX and NDX have turned negative with outperformance in DJIA due to post earning gains in Boeing (BA) despite initially grim metrics as analysts highlight its decline in operating cash flow is much less than feared, despite missing estimate, whilst highlighting the “noise” with its other figures due to the 737 MAX. Apple (AAPL) also firmer following EPS and revenue beats and strong iPhone and wearables revenue, whilst noting very solid demand for its iPhone 11 and AirPods. Dow (DOW) also contributing the outperformance in the DJIA. The gains in Boeing (BA) has seen the industrial sector outperform alongside gains in General Electric (GE), who trade higher on top and bottom line beats. Materials also an outperformer, following solid Dow (DOW) and Avery Dimensions (AVY) earnings. Defensive's (XLU, XLV, XLP) are in the red today however the laggard is Communication services, which is being weighed on by AT&T (T) earnings, which saw disappointing TV metrics. Elsewhere, semiconductors (SOX) open lower today as losses in AMD accelerate post earnings.

subject: McDonald's (MCD) CEO says coronavirus affect on the business is going to be fairly small assuming it remains contained; China represents about 9% of restaurant count, 4-5% of system-wide sales and 3% of operating income

content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Earnings from Apple (AAPL) +2%, Boeing (BA) +3.3% and McDonald’s (MCD) -0.2% and more
  • L Brands Inc. (LB) CEO Les Wexnar is reportedly in discussions to step aside from the position and is also reportedly considering strategic alternatives for its Victoria Secret, according to WSJ.
  • Facebook (FB) upgraded upgraded to a Strong Buy at Raymond James who expect it to report revenue and earnings beats in Q4.

29th January 2020

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) Q1 20 (USD): EPS 4.99 (Exp. 4.55); Revenue 91.82 (exp. 88.50bln), iPhone: 55.96bln (exp. 51.51bln), iPads: 5.98bln (exp. 6.70bln), Mac: 7.16bln (exp. 7.15bln), Services: 12.72bln (exp. 13.07bln), Wearables 10.01bln (including Air Pods): (exp. 9.52bln), Sees Q2 revenue between 63.0-67.0bln (exp. 62.4bln). Declared a dividend of USD 0.71/shr. CEO announced one store has been shut in China and they have restricted employee travel due to the coronavirus. Saw greater China return to growth in Q1 and a blowout quarter for wearables. The tech giant saw record revenue due to strong iPhone demand, and a record net income of USD 22.2bln. Co says its Apple TV+ is off to a rousing start (note that services revenue missed estimates, however), its AirPods demand is phenomenal, especially for AirPods Pro, where the Apple Watch set a new quarter.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) Q4 19 (USD): GAAP loss of 1.79, Adj. Loss of 2.33 (exp. +1.47), Revenue 17.9bln (exp. 21.67bln); Commercial Airplanes Revenue 7.46bln (exp. 9.54bln, prev. 16.53bln Y/Y). "continue to be significantly impacted by the 737 MAX grounding", Operating cash flow -2.22bln (exp. -1.89bln, prev. 2.95bln Y/Y), some highlight this hit is less than feared, despite missing street estimates. Estimated costs to produce 737 aircraft included in accounting quantity increased by 2.6bln in the quarter. Suspension and gradual production resumption at low rates to result in about 4bln of abnormal production costs to be expensed as incurred and primarily in 2020.
  • Dow Inc. (DOW) (Materials/Commodity Chemicals) Q4 19 (USD): Operating EPS 0.78 (exp. 0.74), Revenue 10.20bln (exp. 10.07bln). Expects to further reduce its cost structure over the course of the year as tit completes the stranded cost removal.
  • Goldman Sachs Group (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) announced medium-term target (3-year) of more than 13% RoE and more than 14% RoTE; medium term targets include 13-13.5% CET 1 ratio (exp. FY22 12.42%), ahead of its very first analyst day which is taking place currently.
  • JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) (Financials/Diversified Banks) is to reportedly cut hundreds of jobs at its consumer division, according to people familiar with the matter.
  • McDonald's Corp. (MCD) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) Q4 19 (USD): Ex-tax benefit EPS 1.97 (GAAP 2.08, exp. 1.96), Revenue 5.35bln (exp. 5.3bln); Total SSS +6.2% (exp. +5.2%), US SSS 5.7%, international developmental licensed segment +6.6%. Highlights customer traffic was negative in Q4.

NASDAQ 100

  • Advanced Micro Devices Inc (AMD) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.32, non-adj. 0.15, (exp. 0.31), Revenue 2.13bln (exp. 2.11bln). Q1 20 revenue view 1.8bln (+/- 0.50mln) (exp. 1.84bln). FY20 revenue growth expected at + 28-30% Y/Y, Computing and graphics revenue USD 1.66bln +69% Y/Y, Enterprise, embedded and semi-custom segment revenue + 0.456bln (+7% Y/Y), Q1 Adj. Gross margin view to be to be roughly 46%.

  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) VP of engineering is to leave the company after 10 years at the company, with David Mortensen to be the successor, who has been at Facebook for 9 years, according to CNBC citing a spokesman. Elsewhere, it was upgraded to a Strong Buy at Raymond James who expect it to report revenue and earnings beats in Q4.

  • Starbucks Corp. (SBUX) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) Q1 20 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.79 (exp. 0.76), Revenue 7.1bln (exp. 7.11bln); comp sales +5% globally, SSS +6% in the US, SSS +3% in China; leaves guidance unchanged. Announced it has closed over half of stores in China due to Coronavirus; store closures are expected to materially affect results,
  • Verizon Communications (VZ) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) and Honeywell Int'l Inc. (HON) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) are partnering to help utilities speed up and simplify the deployment of new communication sensors for a smart electric grid.

Says Q4 revenues declined due to pressure in video subscriptions, continued decreases in voice and legacy services, among others, reaffirms 2020 guidance. subject: Fixed and FX latest: bonds and Buck remain in the ascendency
content: Bunds continue to front run core counterparts amidst reports of more ME missile attacks against Saudi sites, obdurate remarks from EU’s Barnier on Brexit, and broadly shrugging off early US data (wider trade gap and mixed wholesale inventories) along the way. The 10 year German benchmark just climbed to a new Eurex high at 174.15, while BTPs have extended their peak to 147.59 as Gilts and US Treasuries hover just below their respective pinnacles. Meanwhile, the Dollar is still outpacing currency peers with the DXY just shy of 98.200.

analysis_details: • Earlier, World Health Organisation spokesperson said WHO believes it is up to governments to decide if they wish to evacuate their nationals from Wuhan, advised Gov'ts to prepare for the possibility of imported cases and has issues necessary guidance

subject: Chinese government says it is to study and implement tax and financial support policies to mitigate effects of the coronavirus outbreak
analysis_details:
• Earlier, Chinese government economist saidChina Q1 growth could fall below 5% due to the virus; forecast is based on the assumption that the virus outbreak will peak by mid-February and end by March-end
  • Some suggested the virus could shed 1ppt off of Chinese GDP, in-line with the worst case estimates from the street
  • For reference 2019 Chinese GDP printed at 6.1% vs. its target of 6.0-6.5%
  • In terms of the global ramifications, at the time of the 2003 SARS outbreak China accounted for around 3% of global GDP whereas now it accounts for just shy of 16%
  • ING note that in 2003 SARS is believed to have taken around 1% off of Chinese GDP
  • Additionally, ING note that uncertainty regarding the virus' spread makes it very difficult to conduct an accurate forecast of its potential impact

  • Beijing is likely to step up policy support for the economy, that could boost the budget deficit to over 3% of GDP this year
  • PBOC might further cut RRRs and rates to provide support
analysis_details:
• Some suggested the virus could shed 1ppt off of Chinese GDP, in-line with the worst case estimates from the street
  • For reference 2019 Chinese GDP printed at 6.1% vs. its target of 6.0-6.5%
  • In terms of the global ramifications, at the time of the 2003 SARS outbreak China accounted for around 3% of global GDP whereas now it accounts for just shy of 16%
  • ING note that in 2003 SARS is believed to have taken around 1% off of Chinese GDP
  • Additionally, ING note that uncertainty regarding the virus' spread makes it very difficult to conduct an accurate forecast of its potential impact

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 29th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are rangebound in a mild reprive from coronavirus, as focus turns to earnings/FOMC
  • SCMP article suggests that the coronavirus could impact Beijing’s ability to meet US-China Phase 1 trade deal import demands
  • World Health Organisation are reportedly to hold a press conference at 14:00GMT on the Coronavirus
  • Apple beat on top and bottom lines, and iPhone sales came in above expectations; 2% higher in pre-market
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Trade, Pending Home Sales, DoEs, FOMC Rate Decision and Press Conference
  • Earnings: Microsoft, Facebook, Mastercard, AT&T, Boeing, Mcdonald's, PayPal, Tesla, Mondelez International, ADP, Marathon Petroleum, Sprint

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

World Health Organisation are reportedly to hold a press conference at 14:00GMT on the Coronavirus. For reference, the World Health Organisation's current classification of the virus is that the risk is very high in China, and high at both a regional and global level. (Newswires) Total number of coronavirus cases in China rose to 5974 and total deaths at 132 as of January 28th according to state media, while the National Health Commission said the total number of suspected coronavirus cases in China was at 9239. (Newswires)

China Global Times tweeted that 11 Wuhan residents traveling back from abroad were found to be infected with the novel coronavirus as of 6am Tuesday citing Chinese customs, while an article in SCMP suggested that the coronavirus could impact Beijing’s ability to meet US-China Phase 1 trade deal import demands, (People’s Daily/Global Times/SCMP)

PBoC Beijing Branch said it will increase funding support to financial institutions under its administration to help tackle coronavirus. (Newswires)

Senior US administration official later commented that White House did not call airlines and did not ask for suspension of flights between US and China. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region found some reprieve following the rebound on Wall St where sentiment was underpinned by vaccine efforts to tackle the coronavirus, touted dip-buying and encouraging US data, while a stellar report from Apple which beat on both top and bottom lines, as well as iPhone revenue added further fuel to equity futures after-hours. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) took impetus from their US peers but with upside somewhat capped as participants also digested a slew of corporate updates, while Tokyo sentiment was driven by recent favourable currency flows and a heavy slate of earnings. Conversely, Hang Seng (-2.8%) suffered a bloodbath on return from the Lunar New Year holiday and briefly slipped into correction territory with heavy losses across a broad range of industries including financials, airliners and retailers due to the coronavirus fears which prompted measures from Hong Kong to reduce cross-border travel with mainland China, while casino stocks were also a losing bet after China stopped issuing individual travel visas for visits to Macau by mainland residents in an effort to control the outbreak. 10yr JGBs were flat after the recovery in risk appetite dampened safe-haven demand, but with downside also stemmed by support at 152.50 and amid the BoJ’s presence for over JPY 1.1tln of JGBs in up to 10yr maturities.

BoJ Summary of Opinions from the January meeting stated there has been no further increase in the possibility that the momentum toward achieving the price stability target will be lost and that it is appropriate to maintain the current guidelines for market operations. BoJ also noted that Japan's economy has been on a moderate expanding trend, although exports, production and business sentiment have shown some weakness, mainly affected by the slowdown in overseas economies and natural disasters. Furthermore, the BoJ stated that although risks concerning overseas economies remain significant, signs of recovery have started to be observed in part and there was the opinion that they may need to conduct review of policy framework given heightening debate in Europe and US over 'Japanification'. (Newswires)

US 

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said the GOP doesn't have the votes to block impeachment witnesses. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK government will introduce a bill into parliament today for legislation to end automatic rights for EU vessels to fish in UK waters. (Newswires)

The Times’ shadow MPC voted 8-1 (1 hawkish dissent) in favour of leaving rates unchanged at 0.75%; cites return of economic confidence and planned budget stimulus. (Times)

Senior Tory backbenchers are considering a HoC revolt to force a total ban on Huawei and there were feelers out last night on how many will back them with 45 Conservative MPs needed to defeat the government, according to Sun's Tom Newton Dunn. (Twitter)

ECB's Rehn says given that negative risks within Europe do not materialise we could then be closer to 1.5% growth for Europe next year, latest information regarding core inflation indicates a rise; ECB has not run out of tools if monetary policy needs to be strengthened. (Newswires)

IMF sees Italian deficit/GDP ration at 2.4% in 2020 (vs. govt's 2.2% target); sees Italy's GDP growth the lowest in EU in coming years, notes that further consolidation is needed in the Italian banking sector. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Turkish President Erdogan told Russia that Turkey is running out of patience regarding the ongoing bombings in Syria's Idlib, via NTV. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European stocks trade modestly in positive territory [Eurostoxx 50 +0.3%] – following on from a similar APAC lead, with the exception of Hong Kong markets which had its first chance to react to the coronavirus developments following its Lunar New Year holiday. Sectors are mostly in the green with material names outperforming, albeit more-so a consolidation from the recent virus-induces losses. Overall, sectors do not reflect a clear risk tone in the equity-space. Individual movers are more earning-orientated; Pharma-giant Novartis (+1.3%) shares rose amid a beat on both revenue and net income forecasts, whilst also forecasting sustained long-term growth, albeit the Co’s core EPS metric missed expectation. LVMH (+0.3%) nursed opening losses of almost 2%, which was initially induced by a 40% YY drop in Hong Kong sales in Q4 amid ongoing unrest in the region; the Co. topped its FY19 forecasts and posted an improvement in operating profit. Santander (+3.5%) extended on its opening gains amid stellar earnings, with share prices underpinned by a 3% boost to its dividend. Elsewhere, Apple (+2% pre-market) earnings have provided tailwinds to the European chip-space, with AMS (+2.5%), STMicroelectronics (+1.2%), Infineon (+1.4%), Dialog Semiconductor (+1.4%) and ASML (+1.3%) all supported in the aftermath. For reference, DJ constituents Boeing and McDonalds will be reported before the bell today and carry weightings of 7.47% and 4.97% respectively.

Apple (AAPL) Q1 '20 earnings (USD): EPS 4.99 (Exp. 4.55); Revenue 91.82 (exp. 88.50bln), iPhone: 55.96bln (exp. 51.51bln), iPads: 5.98bln (exp. 6.70bln), Mac: 7.16bln (exp. 7.15bln), Services: 12.72bln (exp. 13.07bln). (Newswires) NOTE: AAPL has a 4.8% SPX weight; a 11.9% weight in the NDX, and a 7.47% weight in the Dow – Co. shares rose 3% after-market post-results.

eBay Inc (EBAY) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.81 (exp. 0.76), Revenue 2.8bln (exp. 2.81bln); Sees 2020 net revenue 10.72-10.92bln (exp. 11.0bln); boosts share buyback by USD 5bln, raises dividend to 0.16/shr (+14%). (Newswires)

Advanced Micro Devices Inc (AMD) - Q4 19 Adj. EPS USD 0.32 vs. Exp. USD 0.31, Revenue USD 2.13bln vs. Exp. 2.11bln. Q1 20 revenue view USD 1.8bln (+/- 0.50mln) vs. Exp. 1.84bln. (Newswires) Co. shares fell 3.5% in after market trade following soft Q1 revenue forecast

Dow Inc (DOW) Q4 19 (USD): operating EPS 0.78 (exp. 0.74), Revenue 10.20bln (exp. 10.07bln).Co. have a 1.11% DJIA weighting.

LVMH (MC FP) – FY19 revenue EUR 53.7bln vs. Exp. EUR 53.5bln. Adj. net EUR 7.17bln vs. Exp. EUR 7.30bln. Adj. operating profit EUR 11.5bln vs. Prev. EUR 10.0bln. Q4 sales EUR 15.3bln, -11% QQ amid headwinds from Hong Kong. Hong Kong sales -40% YY. (Newswires) NOTE: Co. has a ~1.3% weighting in the Stoxx600 and ~8% weighting in the CAC40.

Novartis (NOVN SW) – Q4 revenue USD 12.40bln vs. Exp. USD 12.36bln. Net income USD 2.8bln vs. Exp. USD 2.6bln. Core operating profit USD 3.46bln vs. Exp. USD 3.54bln. Core EPS USD 1.32 vs. Exp. USD 1.33. Co. says net sales are expected to grow mid to high-single digits, Core operating income expected to grow high-single to low double-digits. Co. expects to sustain long-term growth and margin expansion, driven by market growth drivers and 15 ongoing or upcoming major launches. Co. does not see any disruptions to supply chain due to coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires) NOTE: Co. has ~2.3% weighting in the Stoxx 600 and ~18% weighting in the SMI.

Santander (SAN SM) – Q4 net income EUR 2.8bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.6bln. Revenue EUR 12.6bln vs. Prev. 12.5bln. Co. is to raise dividend 3% to EUR 0.23/shr. NII EUR 8.84bln vs. Prev. EUR 8.81bln QQ, ROTE 12.62% vs. Prev. 9.86% QQ. CET1 ratio 11.65% vs. Prev. 11.3% QQ. Net loans EUR 942.2bln vs. Prev. EUR 916bln QQ. Co. guides initial FY20 CET1 close to 12%. Co. is confident on reaching mid-term targets, seeing annualised high-single digit growth EPS over the next three years. (Newswires)

FX

USD - The Dollar remains firm almost across the board, and especially vs EM currency peers that are more sensitive to risk aversion and prone to swings in market sentiment. The DXY continues to straddle 98.000 as several major pairings rotate around round numbers in tight confines ahead of the Fed that is likely to provide clearer direction via guidance and the tone of Chair Powell’s first post-meeting press conference of the New Year. In the interim, prelim trade and wholesale inventories may offer some impetus ahead of pending home sales, while any further updates on China’s coronavirus will also be pivotal.

JPY/SEK - Bucking the broad trend of underperformance vs the Greenback, the Yen is grinding back up towards the 109.00 level from 109.26 or so lows amidst a wider recovery in safe-haven assets, including Gold and global bonds, as the US Treasury curve flips back in to bull-flattening mode. Meanwhile, the Swedish Krona is also paring more losses vs the Euro after yesterday’s knee-jerk decline post-soft data (overall) with some momentum from an improvement in industrial sentiment over consumer confidence that dipped, with Eur/Sek probing the lower end of 10.5965-5630 parameters.

GBP/AUD/CAD/EUR/CHF/NZD - All softer against the Usd to varying degrees, as Cable clings to 1.3000 in advance of Thursday’s eagerly awaited BoE rate call that is seen on a knife edge, while the Aussie is holding in above 0.6750 with assistance from firmer than forecast Q4 CPI metrics and supportive Aud/Nzd cross winds as the Kiwi falters close to Tuesday’s lows within a 0.6527-52 band awaiting NZ trade data later tonight. Elsewhere, the Loonie is gleaning some traction via firmer oil prices to consolidate between 1.3155-76 compared to 1.3200+ at one stage yesterday, but the Euro is still struggling to bounce from around 1.1000 after sub-consensus Eurozone M3 growth, and remains depressed vs the Franc in the low 1.0700 area even though Usd/Chf is hugging the top of 0.9750-27 extremes in wake of a fall in Swiss ZEW investor morale.

EM - In contrast to the aforementioned general depreciation against the Dollar, the offshore Yuan is sustaining recovery momentum on hopes that the worst of the health scare may be over soon, while the Rand is keeping its head just above 14.6000 following Moody’s decision that it is too early to review SA’s credit standing and post-budget will be more appropriate.

Australian CPI (Q4) Q/Q 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%) Australian CPI (Q4) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%) Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI (Q4) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.4%) Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI (Q4) Y/Y 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.6%) Australian RBA Weighted Median CPI (Q4) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.3%) Australian RBA Weighted Median CPI (Q4) Y/Y 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.2%)

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

-        USD/CAD: 1.3065-80 (1BLN), 1.3100 (390M), 1.3125 (1.1BLN), 1.3150 (260M)

-        AUD/JPY: 73.00 (1.3BLN)

FIXED

It’s been a relatively slow grind, but no less compelling and perhaps fulfilling rebound across bond land, as Bunds completed a 180 degree turnaround before having a glance over 174.05 and then easing back after a so-so 5 year German auction, while Gilts edged a marginal new 134.82 Liffe high and US Treasuries topped out at 130-27. However, Italian BTPs are still leading the complex and hit 147.54 at best on more political relief and little in the way of syndication issues. Ahead, some US data to digest before Wednesday’s main course and afters in the form of the FOMC and Fed chair Powell.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures remain on consolidation-mode and hold onto most of their APAC gains, with prices somewhat relieved by the latest private inventory report. Headline crude posted a surprise draw of 4.27mln barrels vs. expectations for a 500k barrel build. Desks note that price action W/W suggest that markets see a substantial demand impact from the coronavirus outbreak, with airlines continuing to suspend travels to and from China. Demand side implications could be significantly impacted – contingent on the strictness of the travel restrictions and the time frame – which may prompt OPEC+ to revaluate their output cut pact. ING notes that prolonged pressure on oil prices could lead to deeper cuts by the oil-rich countries, although Libya’s current oil disruptions may help in regard to the scope of cuts Saudi and Russia could take on. Sources yesterday highlighted a slight shift in Russia’s stance, who prefers exiting the pact in March – but may be willing to stay on if Brent prices remain sub-60/bbl. That said, Russian Energy Minister Novak stated that the country's tax system may pose risks to Russia's ability to maintain oil output. Elsewhere spot gold has clambered off overnight lows as DXY pulled back from yesterday’s high, with the yellow metal on standby for significant macro developments ahead of the FOMC rate decision later today. Similarly, copper prices have experienced relatively muted price action thus far following six consecutive sessions of losses.

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (w/e 24th Jan) -4.3mln (exp. +0.5mln, prev. +1.6mln). (Newswires) 

Libya NOC said oil production on January 27th was at 271k bpd which was slightly up from the prior day. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak notes that the country's tax system may pose risks to Russia's ability to maintain oil output, via IFAX. (IFAX)

content: The 10 year German debt future has erased all and a bit more of its extended declines from the Eurex open after resuming trade just 2 ticks below yesterday’s 173.68 close and reversing further to 173.41 at one stage. This matched Monday’s intraday base and may have prompted some buyers to step in given no follow through selling on stops more than a full point down from Tuesday’s early high (173.48). However, the 173.94-97 area could form near term resistance ahead of 174.00 (vs 173.83 high so far), while BTPs are probing higher again and giving peripheral peers a lift and bonds will also be eyeing stocks as a proxy for sentiment surrounding China’s deadly virus. **EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

29th January 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets were mostly higher as the region found some reprieve following the rebound on Wall St where sentiment was underpinned by vaccine efforts to tackle the coronavirus, touted dip-buying and encouraging US data, while a stellar report from Apple which beat on both top and bottom lines, as well as iPhone revenue added further fuel to equity futures after-hours. As such, ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) took impetus from their US peers but with upside somewhat capped as participants also digested a slew of corporate updates including Treasury Wine Estates which fell over 20% after lowering its guidance, while Tokyo sentiment was driven by recent favourable currency flows and a heavy slate of earnings. Conversely, Hang Seng (-2.6%) suffered a bloodbath on return from the Lunar New Year holiday and briefly slipped into correction territory with heavy losses across a broad range of industries including financials, airliners and retailers due to the coronavirus fears which prompted measures from Hong Kong to reduce cross-border travel with mainland China, while casino stocks were also a losing bet after China stopped issuing individual travel visas for visits to Macau by mainland residents in an effort to control the outbreak.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 29th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region found some reprieve following the rebound on Wall St
  • Total number of coronavirus cases in China rose to 5974 and total deaths at 132 as of Jan 28th
  • People's Daily reported the coronavirus outbreak may reach its peak in one week or around 10 days
  • SCMP suggested that the coronavirus could impact Beijing’s ability to meet US-China Phase 1 trade deal import demands
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German GFK Consumer Sentiment, US Trade, Pending Home Sales, DoEs, FOMC Rate Decision and Press Conference, supply from Germany
  • Earnings: Microsoft, Facebook, Mastercard, AT&T, Boeing, Mcdonald's, PayPal, Tesla, General Electric, Mondelez International, ADP, Marathon Petroleum, Sprint, Novartis, Santander

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Total number of coronavirus cases in China rose to 5974 and total deaths at 132 as of January 28th according to state media, while the National Health Commission said the total number of suspected coronavirus cases in China was at 9239. (Newswires)

People's Daily reported the coronavirus outbreak may reach its peak in one week or around 10 days and then there will be no large-scale increases citing a renowned Chinese respiratory expert Zhong Nanshan. In related news, China Global Times tweeted that 11 Wuhan residents traveling back from abroad were found to be infected with the novel coronavirus as of 6am Tuesday citing Chinese customs, while an article in SCMP suggested that the coronavirus could impact Beijing’s ability to meet US-China Phase 1 trade deal import demands, (People’s Daily/Global Times/SCMP)

PBoC Beijing Branch said it will increase funding support to financial institutions under its administration to help tackle coronavirus. (Newswires)

US NIH official said they hope to advance coronavirus vaccine into Phase 1 trials within three months, while there were separate comments from the US Health Secretary that the use of face masks in the US to counter coronavirus is not necessary as the risks to individuals are currently very low. (Newswires)

White House was reportedly mulling China travel restrictions and told airlines it may suspend all China-US flight amid coronavirus outbreak, while other reports also stated that the White House was monitoring China-US flights but decided against suspending air traffic on Tuesday and that it is holding daily meetings in which it could revisit the idea of suspending China-US flights. However, a senior US administration official later commented that White House did not call airlines and did not ask for suspension of flights between US and China. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region found some reprieve following the rebound on Wall St where sentiment was underpinned by vaccine efforts to tackle the coronavirus, touted dip-buying and encouraging US data, while a stellar report from Apple which beat on both top and bottom lines, as well as iPhone revenue added further fuel to equity futures after-hours. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) took impetus from their US peers but with upside somewhat capped as participants also digested a slew of corporate updates, while Tokyo sentiment was driven by recent favourable currency flows and a heavy slate of earnings. Conversely, Hang Seng (-2.6%) suffered a bloodbath on return from the Lunar New Year holiday and briefly slipped into correction territory with heavy losses across a broad range of industries including financials, airliners and retailers due to the coronavirus fears which prompted measures from Hong Kong to reduce cross-border travel with mainland China, while casino stocks were also a losing bet after China stopped issuing individual travel visas for visits to Macau by mainland residents in an effort to control the outbreak. 10yr JGBs were flat after the recovery in risk appetite dampened safe-haven demand, but with downside also stemmed by support at 152.50 and amid the BoJ’s presence for over JPY 1.1tln of JGBs in up to 10yr maturities.

BoJ Summary of Opinions from the January meeting stated there has been no further increase in the possibility that the momentum toward achieving the price stability target will be lost and that it is appropriate to maintain the current guidelines for market operations. BoJ also noted that Japan's economy has been on a moderate expanding trend, although exports, production and business sentiment have shown some weakness, mainly affected by the slowdown in overseas economies and natural disasters. Furthermore, the BoJ stated that although risks concerning overseas economies remain significant, signs of recovery have started to be observed in part and there was the opinion that they may need to conduct review of policy framework given heightening debate in Europe and US over 'Japanification'. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK government will introduce a bill into parliament today for legislation to end automatic rights for EU vessels to fish in UK waters. (Newswires)

 

The Times’ shadow MPC voted 8-1 (1 hawkish dissent) in favour of leaving rates unchanged at 0.75%; cites return of economic confidence and planned budget stimulus. (Times)

 

Senior Tory backbenchers are considering a HoC revolt to force a total ban on Huawei and there were feelers out last night on how many will back them with 45 Conservative MPs needed to defeat the government, according to Sun's Tom Newton Dunn. (Twitter)

US Republican Senator Graham said the UK's decision for Huawei could "greatly complicate" a free trade agreement between the two sides, while a report also noted that US Politicians are said to be ‘furious’ at the UK’s decision on Huawei with some suggesting they could take a harder line in post-Brexit trade negotiations as a result. (Newswires/LBC)

 

UK BRC Shop Price Index (Jan) Y/Y -0.3% (Prev. -0.4%). (Newswires)

 

FX

DXY was steady and held above 98.00 following the mild support from better than expected data, although overnight price action was relatively contained. EUR/USD was rangebound after rebounding from support at 1.1000 and GBP/USD was indecisive just north of 1.3000 ahead of the BoE meeting on Thursday. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were initially supported by the improvement in global risk sentiment although have since plateaued, while antipodeans traded mixed with AUD underpinned after Q4 inflation data which showed headline CPI Q/Q and Y/Y topped estimates, which led to RBC revising its RBA rate cut forecast to June from Q1 and JPMorgan also pushed back its rate cut call to May from February.

Australian CPI (Q4) Q/Q 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%) Australian CPI (Q4) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%) Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI (Q4) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.4%) Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI (Q4) Y/Y 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.6%) Australian RBA Weighted Median CPI (Q4) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.3%) Australian RBA Weighted Median CPI (Q4) Y/Y 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.2%)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures extended on the gains seen during the prior session, while further upside was spurred following bullish private sector inventory data which showed a surprise draw in headline crude stockpiles. Elsewhere, gold remained lacklustre as safe havens were shunned due to the rebound in global equities which also underpinned copper to reclaim the USD 2.60/lb level. 

 

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (w/e 24th Jan) -4.3mln (exp. +0.5mln, prev. +1.6mln). (Newswires) 

Libya NOC said oil production on January 27th was at 271k bpd which was slightly up from the prior day. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

 

US and Israel proposed a two-state solution for Israel and Palestine with the Palestine capital in Jerusalem. Israel agreed to negotiate on the basis of a detailed proposed map, while agreement for statehood for Palestinians is contingent on security arrangements to protect Israelis, as well as Palestine’s respect for human rights, freedom of press and transparent judiciary. US President Trump commented that this is the first time Israel has authorized the release of a proposed and consensual map for an Israeli-Palestinian peace plan, although the President of the State of Palestine Abbas stated the deal plot will not pass and Jerusalem is not for sale, while a Hamas official also described the peace plan as 'aggressive' and as 'nonsense'. (Newswires)

US 

Yields were higher across the curve by between 2.5-4.5bps, at settlement, with the shape of the curve marginally steeper. It helped the 2s5s and 3m/10-year spreads to both go positive, having briefly inverting in the last 24hrs. A more constructive risk tone was cited. The US Treasury sold 7-year notes, tailing 0.4bps (the 2s, 5s, and 7s auctions have all tailed this week), though cover was in line with recent averages. The internals were more or less in line with recent averages; Directs took 17.2% against recent average of 15.7%; indirects took 58.1% against an average of 61.5%, while dealers were left with 24.7% against recent average of 22.7%. US T-note futures settled 9 ticks lower at 130-19+.

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said the GOP doesn't have the votes to block impeachment witnesses. (Newswires)

Apple (AAPL) Q1 '20 earnings (USD): EPS 4.99 (Exp. 4.55); Revenue 91.82 (exp. 88.50bln), iPhone: 55.96bln (exp. 51.51bln), iPads: 5.98bln (exp. 6.70bln), Mac: 7.16bln (exp. 7.15bln), Services: 12.72bln (exp. 13.07bln). (Newswires)

eBay Inc (EBAY) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.81 (exp. 0.76), Revenue 2.8bln (exp. 2.81bln); Sees 2020 net revenue 10.72-10.92bln (exp. 11.0bln); boosts share buyback by USD 5bln, raises dividend to 0.16/shr (+14%). (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Reprieve seen for most of Asia, aside from the stockmarket bloodbath in Hong Kong on return from holiday
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly higher as the region gets some reprieve following the rebound on Wall St where sentiment was underpinned by vaccine efforts to tackle the coronavirus, touted dip-buying and encouraging US data, while a stellar report from Apple which beat on both top and bottom lines, as well as iPhone revenue added further fuel to equity futures after-hours. As such, ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) took impetus from their US peers but with upside somewhat limited as participants also digest a slew of corporate updates including Treasury Wine Estates which fell over 20% after lowering its guidance, while Tokyo sentiment is driven by favourable currency flows and a heavy slate of earnings. Conversely, Hang Seng (-2.6%) suffers a bloodbath on return from the Lunar New Year holiday with heavy losses across a broad range of industries including financials, airliners and retailers due to the coronavirus fears which has prompted measures from Hong Kong to reduce cross-border travel with mainland China, while gambling stocks also slumped after China stopped issuing individual travel visas for visits to Macau by mainland residents in an effort to control the outbreak.

In FX markets, the DXY is steady and holds above the 98.00 level following the mild support from better than expected data including US Consumer Confidence and Durable Goods, although overnight price action has been sideways as participants look ahead to the FOMC decision later today. EUR/USD is rangebound after having rebounded from support at 1.1000 and GBP/USD is indecisive just north of 1.3000 ahead of the BoE meeting on Thursday which markets perceive to be a coin toss. Furthermore, the UK government’s decision to permit Huawei involvement in the domestic 5G network is said to complicate a US-UK trade agreement and has spurred some senior Tory backbenchers to consider a Commons revolt to force a total ban on Huawei. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are supported by the improvement in global risk sentiment, while antipodeans are mixed with AUD/USD underpinned after Q4 inflation data which showed headline CPI Q/Q and Y/Y topped estimates, which led to RBC revising its RBA rate cut forecast to June from Q1 and JPMorgan also pushed back its call to May from February.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat as the recovery in risk appetite dampens safe-haven demand, but with downside stemmed by support at 152.50 and amid the BoJ’s presence for over JPY 1.1tln of JGBs in up to 10yr maturities.

content:
China Maple Leaf Educational Systems (1317 HK) - Co. announced offer for Kingsley valued at HKD 431mln. (Newswires)

Kaz Minerals (847 HK) - Co. completed amendment and extension of its pre-export finance loan facility. (Newswires)

SSY Group (2005 HK) - Co. notes antiviral drug Abidol Capsule has been included under list of emergency procurements in China. (Newswires)

 

Huawei

UK Government granted permission for Huawei to construct non-core sections of the UK telecom network although it has been designated a high-risk vendor and will have a market share cap of 35%, while it will be excluded from sensitive geographic locations. (Newswires)

EU will not ban Huawei from their telecommunications network but will be imposing strict 5G rules, according to AFP citing an Official. (AFP)

 

PBoC

PBoC stated that the Central Bank will offer abundant liquidity after the Lunar New Year Holiday through Open Market Operations, while it confirmed the interbank market will remain closed until February 3rd and it is considering the large-scale funds due for redemption after markets reopen. (Newswires)

PBoC Beijing Branch said it will increase funding support to financial institutions under its administration to help tackle coronavirus. (Newswires)

 

Coronavirus

Total number of coronavirus cases in China at 5974 and total deaths at 132 as of January 28th, while the National Health Commission said the total number of suspected coronavirus cases in China is at 9239 as of January 28th. (Newswires)

World Health Organisation stated that they have not seen any onward human-to-human spread of coronavirus by travellers returning from China, aside from one case in Vietnam which is good news. However, there were reports that a man in Germany was infected with the coronavirus from a woman who travelled to Wuhan which is being portrayed as person-to-person transmission, although it was unclear if this is explicitly the case. (Newswires/Focus)

People's Daily reported the coronavirus outbreak may reach its peak in one week or around 10 days and then there will be no large-scale increases, according to renowned Chinese respiratory expert Zhong Nanshan. (People’s Daily)

Hong Kong researchers have developed the coronavirus vaccine although it would take months to test it on animals and at least another year to conduct clinical trials, according to reports in SCMP citing a disease expert. In related news, Global Times noted that China is likely to have a public use vaccine for the Coronavirus within 3-months citing a Chinese Academy of Engineering academic. (SCMP/Global Times)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam announced plans to reduce cross-border travel between the city and mainland China due to the coronavirus, while China reportedly suspended issuing travel permits to Macau. (Newswires)

US NIH official said they hope to advance coronavirus vaccine into Phase 1 trials within three months, while there were separate comments from the US Health Secretary that the use of face masks in the US to counter coronavirus is not necessary as the risks to individuals are currently very low. (Newswires)

White House is mulling China travel restrictions and told airlines it may suspend all China-US flight amid coronavirus outbreak. However, reports later stated that the White House was monitoring China-US flights but decided against suspending air traffic on Tuesday, while it is holding daily meetings on coronavirus and may revisit the idea of suspending China-US flights. (Newswires)

A fourth case of coronavirus has been confirmed in France and there were separate reports of a suspected coronavirus case in Birmingham, UK in which a person felt ill after returning from Wuhan. (Figaro/Daily Mail)
